Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Magnetic Fields on Planetary to Cosmic Scales - a Joint Program in Astronomy and Space Science at Boston University
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will establish a new Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at Boston University (BU). The REU program will be offered annually to six qualified applicants, who will perform cutting-edge research with dedicated faculty members. The Site will leverage BU?s expertise in studying magnetic fields at all cosmic scales, in order to impart a deep understanding of the basics of electromagnetism to the REU students. Student projects will be selected from topics that will expose undergraduate researchers to magnetic-field phenomena in the universe and cover topics including solar physics, auroral and ionospheric physics, and heliospheric science, as well as magnetic fields on stars, exoplanets, blazars, and clusters of galaxies. Potential projects will involve both theory and data analysis from space physics missions and astronomical facilities such as the Discovery Channel Telescope.

By offering high-quality research experiences to students at a critical stage of undergraduate education, the REU Site will contribute to increasing the nationwide pool of scientists and engineers. Participants must come to grips with a large corpus of existing knowledge about the makeup, origins, and interactions of many types of physical and astronomical objects. They will also develop the analytical skills (mathematical, computational, and logical) necessary to process data, understand primary research, and to remain current with new developments in the field. The REU Site also has an active and highly developed strategy to recruit women and underrepresented minorities into its program, which will expand STEM training opportunities to these groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF REU program took place at BU from 2015-2017. The NSF REU site at BU was enourmsly successful. The Astronomy Department at BU hope to renew this project in the near future. Each year we hosted between 6-7 students pairing them with a faculty member/research mentor. They took part of the group of that faculty member/research mentor and participated actively in that group research. 

The culmination of their research involved presenting their research in a one day conference that all the members (faculty/students/reseachers) of the Astronomy Department at BU attended. They also had the option of having their research presented at a national conference (AAS/AGU) with everything paid as well. The students received support for the travel and housing/meals at BU. 

Besides the research taken they had a ten-week program with weekly seminars that included professional development. For the first two years Dr. Julie Skinner ran the weekly seminars. while in the last year these were run by Mr. Marc Kornbleuth. The success of a senior graduate student in this role showed us that their participation should be incorporated into our future REU design. Marc extended the weekly seminars of professional development and included a final presentation day where all the REU students presented their work for the full faculty.

The research undertaken were selected that will exposed undergraduate researchers to magnetic field phenomena in the universe and cover topics including (solar physics, auroral and ionospheric physics (on the Earth and other planets), and heliospheric science, as well as magnetic fields on stars, from active M dwarfs to T-Tauri stars, extra-solar planets, disks around young stellar objects, blazars, and clusters of galaxies.  Potential projects involved both theory and data analysis, including exposure to space physics missions and astronomical facilities and will take advantage of BU’s partnership with the Discovery Channel Telescope and other ground and space-based missions such as HST, Maven, LSST, Voyager, IBEX, and SOHO. 

The Department of Astronomy at Boston University (BU) is unique in that it has a broad mix of expertise that spans many topics in both space physics and astrophysics and covers scales from the Earth’s magnetosphere to supermassive black holes.  At most universities, this range of topics can only be found by combining multiple departments, where administrative, geographic and political barriers can often discourage active interaction.  In the BU Astronomy program, the graduate and undergraduate students are trained in both space physics and astrophysics and leave the program with a rich perspective on the full range of the physics that occurs beyond the Earth.  The REU site built on this synergy with the goal of extending the same experience to undergraduate researchers from other institutions. 

A further description of the success of the program can be found in 

https://www.bu.edu/federal/2017/07/21/nsf-program-brings-budding-astronomers-to-bu/

            Below we attach two photos of the program. On the left: Mr Kornbleuth running the weekly seminars, and on the right: the REU student Mr. Hubbard participating in PI Opher’s research group. Overall, we found that the presence of the REU students energized the groups and research done at Boston University.
